column2: Lasting for a very short time.

column3: His churlish behavior at the party offended several guests.

column2: Inclined to lay down principles as incontrovertibly true.
column3: The dogmatic professor was unwilling to consider alternative theories.

column2: The ability to produce a desired or intended result.

column2: The action or process of flowing or flowing out; continuous change.

column2: (Of a phrase or idea) lacking significance through having been overused; unoriginal and trite.

column2: Wanting to avoid activity or exertion; lazy.

column2: A huge, powerful, and overwhelming force or institution.

column2: Act in an excessively subservient manner.

column2: Give a lot of public attention and approval to (someone); treat as a celebrity.

column2: Self-pityingly or tearfully sentimental, often through drunkenness.

column2: A subtle difference in or shade of meaning, expression, or sound.

column2: Prevent from happening; make impossible.

column2: A mischievous person.

column2: The use of fallacious arguments, especially with the intention of deceiving.

column2: Travel across or through.

column2: Find fault with (someone); scold.

column2: Relating to deep inward feelings rather than to the intellect.

column2: The top or highest part of something, especially one forming a point.

column2: Support or strengthen; prop up.

column2: Hasty and therefore not thorough or detailed.

column2: Deceitfulness; double-dealing.

column2: (Of a disease or condition) regularly found among particular people or in a certain area.

column2: Instigate or stir up (an undesirable or violent sentiment or course of action).

column2: Use gestures, especially dramatic ones, instead of speaking or to emphasize one's words.

column2: A situation in which no progress is possible, especially because of disagreement; a deadlock.

column2: A rebel or revolutionary.

column2: (Of a quality or state) existing but not yet developed or manifest; hidden or concealed.

column2: Make less severe, serious, or painful.

column2: Famous for something bad.

column2: A seemingly absurd or self-contradictory statement or proposition that when investigated or explained may prove to be well founded or true.
column3: It's a paradox that a country so rich in resources can have so much poverty.

column2: (Of language or style) concise and forcefully expressive.

column2: A consequence of an action or event, especially when complex or unwelcome.

column2: Making a show of being morally superior to other people.
column3: Her sanctimonious lectures about virtue were irritating to those who knew her true character.

column2: Prevent or hinder the progress of.
column3: Lack of funding threatened to stymie the research project.

column2: Characterized by conflict, disorder, or confusion; not controlled or calm.
column3: The country experienced a turbulent period of political unrest.

column2: Having or showing a lack of thought or intelligence; mindless.
column3: She gave a vacuous smile, clearly not understanding the question.

column2: Excite or stimulate (someone's desire, interest, or appetite).

column2: (Of something bad) experienced or present to the maximum degree; (of a person or their behavior) completely without pride or dignity.
column3: They lived in abject poverty, with barely enough food to survive.

column2: Deprived of or lacking something, especially a nonmaterial asset.
column3: After his dog died, he felt completely bereft.

column2: Seeming difficult to deal with in anticipation; intimidating.
column3: The task of climbing Mount Everest is a daunting one.

column2: Make (something) clear; explain.

column2: Intense and passionate feeling.

column2: Impressive and imposing in appearance or style, especially pretentiously so.

column2: About to happen.
column3: The dark clouds suggested that a storm was imminent.

column2: Originating or occurring naturally in a particular place; native.

column2: Affected by lethargy; sluggish and apathetic.

column2: Appease the anger or anxiety of (someone).

column2: Make legally null and void; invalidate.

column2: Apparently or purportedly, but perhaps not actually.

column2: (Of a child) having developed certain abilities or proclivities at an earlier age than usual.

column2: Bitterness or resentfulness, especially when long-standing.

column2: Examine or inspect closely and thoroughly.

column2: Kept secret, especially because it would not be approved of.

column2: A principle or belief, especially one of the main principles of a religion or philosophy.
column3: One of the basic tenets of their faith is the importance of compassion.

column2: Check or prove the validity or accuracy of (something).

column2: (Chiefly of large mammals) roll about or lie relaxed in mud or water, especially to keep cool, avoid biting insects, or spread scent. (Of a person) indulge in an unrestrained way in (something that creates a pleasurable sensation).
column3: The hippos like to wallow in the cool mud on hot days.

column2: Having an irritatingly strong and unpleasant taste or smell.

column2: Abrupt or offhand in speech or manner.

column2: Wary and unwilling to take risks.

column2: Spread (something, especially information) widely.

column2: Not even or regular in pattern or movement; unpredictable.

column2: Inspiring fear or respect through being impressively large, powerful, intense, or capable.

column2: Sly or cunning intelligence.
column3: He used his guile and charm to get what he wanted.

column2: Unable to be upset or excited; calm.

column2: Existing in something as a permanent, essential, or characteristic attribute.

column2: Furiously angry.

column2: (Of a decision, event, or change) of great importance or significance, especially in its bearing on the future.
column3: The signing of the peace treaty was a momentous occasion.

column2: Annoyingly insensitive or slow to understand.

column2: (Of an action or gesture) carried out with a minimum of effort or reflection.

column2: Spending money or resources freely and recklessly; wastefully extravagant.
column3: The prodigal son returned home after squandering his inheritance.

column2: Filled or well-supplied with something.

column2: The state of being sober; seriousness.

column2: Slender and elegant.

column2: Swollen and distended or congested; (of language or style) tediously pompous or bombastic.

column2: A group of people leading the way in new developments or ideas.

column2: Attractive or appealing in appearance or character.
column3: Her winsome smile charmed everyone she met.

column2: Difficulties; misfortune.

column2: Lay siege to; beset with difficulties.

column2: (Of an argument or case) clear, logical, and convincing.
column3: She presented a cogent argument that persuaded the committee.

column2: Relentlessly severe, stern, or gloomy in manner or appearance.
column3: The dour expression on his face never seemed to change.

column2: (Especially of an official body) absolve (someone) from blame for a fault or wrongdoing, especially after due consideration of the case.

column2: (Typically of children) irritable and quarrelsome. (Of a group or organization) difficult to control; unruly.

column2: Leadership or dominance, especially by one country or social group over others.
column3: The nation sought regional hegemony through economic and military power.

column2: Not allowing fluid to pass through; unable to be affected by.
column3: The raincoat was made of material impervious to water.

column2: Impossible to understand or interpret.

column2: Lacking enthusiasm and determination; carelessly lazy.

column2: Having or showing a wish to do evil to others.

column2: (Astronomy) A cloud of gas and dust in outer space, visible in the night sky either as an indistinct bright patch or as a dark silhouette against other luminous matter.
column3: The telescope revealed the stunning colors of the distant nebula.

column2: (Of a time) well-chosen or particularly favorable or appropriate.
column3: He arrived at the most opportune moment to help them.

column2: (Of a treatment or medicine) relieving pain or alleviating a problem without dealing with the underlying cause.

column2: An inclination or natural tendency to behave in a particular way.

column2: Admirably purposeful, determined, and unwavering.
column3: She was resolute in her decision to pursue her dreams.

column2: Dark or dull in color or tone; gloomy.

column2: (Of a person) calm, dependable, and showing little emotion or animation.

column2: Understood or implied without being stated.

column2: Offense or annoyance.

column2: Make (someone) weak and infirm.

column2: (Of a price or amount charged) unreasonably high.

column2: Not in harmony or keeping with the surroundings or other aspects of something.

column2: (Of an action, idea, or goal) deserving praise and commendation.

column2: (Of a person) subject to sudden or unpredictable changes of mood or mind.

column2: (Of a role or status) existing in name only. (Of a price or charge) very small; far below the real value or cost.

column2: Remove (a need or difficulty).

column2: (Especially of something written or spoken) briefly and clearly expressed.
column3: Her instructions were succinct and easy to follow.

column2: Unnecessary, especially through being more than enough.

column2: Vigorous or incisive in expression or style.

column2: Having a ready insight into and understanding of things.

column3: She faced the crisis with remarkable equanimity.

column2: A tendency to choose or do something regularly; an inclination or predisposition toward a particular thing.

column2: (Of a person or their tendencies) not able to be corrected, improved, or reformed.

column2: The quality of being pleasing to the ear, especially through a harmonious combination of words.

column2: Flamboyant confidence of style or manner.

column2: The ability to act or speak appropriately in social situations.

column2: A policy or attitude of letting things take their own course, without interfering.

column2: "A formal word used to describe things that seriously impair strength or the ability to function."
